thread.title: ARM flexes earnings 34% but falls short of forecast, with Apple to weigh
thread.title_full: ARM flexes earnings 34% but falls short of forecast, with Apple to weigh

title: ARM flexes earnings 34% but falls short of forecast, with Apple to weigh
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 22, 2015, 09:08 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 22 mins ARM flexes earnings 34% but falls short of forecast, with Apple to weigh By Oliver Haill | Sharecast – 33 minutes ago 1,005.00 -34.0000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - After major customer Apple (NasdaqGS: AAPL - news ) disappointed with earnings overnight, ARM Holdings (LSE: ARM.L - news ) is likely to open lower as its own earnings rose by 34% to 7.28p per share but fell short of expectations. City analysts had been hoping for earnings per share of 7.5p, up from the previous year's 5.4p. The microchip designer lifted profits before tax 32% to £123.9m on revenue that rose 22% to £228.5m or 15% in dollar terms to $357.1m. 
Processor licensing revenue in US$ up 3% year-on-year, with royalty revenue in US$ up 31% year-on-year. 
With net cash generation in the quarter at £93.3m, the interim dividend was hiked 25% to 3.15p per share. 
"Q2 2015 has been a strong quarter for ARM with a highly diverse range of leading companies choosing to license ARM's latest processors and physical IP for their future product developments," said chief executive Simon Segars. 
He said that following ARM's investment in improved technology products for mobile devices, the automotive sector and enterprise infrastructure, the company had signed licences for many of these new products. 
"This licensing activity will help to grow the royalty revenue opportunity for years to come," he added. 
Overnight, Apple, thought to be ARM's largest customer, also fell short of analyst's consensus expectations in the third quarter and with its projections for the fourth. The California company revealed it sold 47.5m iPhones in the third quarter, up 35% on the same period last year but short of analysts' expectations of 48.8m. IPad sales fell 18% to 10.9m, the sixth consecutive quarter of declines. 
Apple guided towards revenues of between $49bn and $51bn in its fourth quarter, shy of the $51.1bn consensus forecast.
